body.content: [MUSIC PLAYING]

WILL WRIGHT: Within these
games, within these worlds,

there are a lot of moving
parts, a lot of dynamics.

You want this to be a rich,
interesting environment
for the player to explore.

My approach has always
been to step back and think
of this whole thing as a system.

What is the system
that's happening here?

And actually, when you get down
to the engineering of things

like simulations,
you really do need
to think of it as a system.

And you need to think about
it, what is my paradigm?

What is the way in which I'm
going to structure the world?

What is the way in which I'm
going to structure the world?
How is it going to operate?
What are the parts?

How do they interact
with each other?
Systems are interesting.

In some sense,
what they're going

to lead us to is this idea
that everybody in a game

is going to be exploring the
possibility space of that game.

Where are all the
possible states
that that world could be in?

For something like chess,
it's fairly obvious,

For something like chess,
it's fairly obvious,

although it's a very
big, branching tree.
It's a branching tree.

Every move in chess leads to
another set of possible moves.

And you unfold that branching
tree of all the possible moves

of chess and you come up
with an astronomical number,
but it's still finite.

There are a finite number
of possible states in chess.

The very early games had
very simple branching trees,
very much like chess.

Basically, structure branching
trees that were explicitly
put there by the designer.

And this is very much
like one of those old
choose your own adventure books.
choose your own adventure books.

If you're going to go into
the cave, go to page 7.

If you're going to go to the
top of the hill, go to page 20.

But basically, the
writer's having

to fill out every possible
branch of that book.

So it's a very limited
structure, a very limited world
to explore.

Later games started doing what
I call gated experiences, a game
like, let's say, Quake or Doom.

You're within a level and
you have all this agency

and freedom within that
level, but until you

get through the level and get
to that locked door at the end,

basically, you're
in this little room,

this little, small regional
possibility of space.

this little, small regional
possibility of space.

Once you get through
that, it opens

another regional
possibility of space.

So you basically have
these little islands

of possibility of space
with gates between them.

And then there have been basic
hybrids of these two models
over time.

But then as players
and designers

started building more
open-ended simulations,
it opened up a lot more.

So as we started building
open-ended games--

sandbox games, Grand
Theft Auto, Sims--

we're actually looking
at a possibility of space
that's vast, large.

And this is when we
really have to now view it

And this is when we
really have to now view it

as a system, not as a
branching tree of possibility.

We're not going to map
out every possibility.

What we're going to
do is we're going

to build a set of things
that interact in a way

to, basically, generate
these possibilities for us.

For the Sims, the
way I visualized

it was that, basically,
you had two directions you
could go for achievement.

You go for social achievement
or material achievement.

You could try to make a
lot of friends in the Sims,

build a big family,
have people like you.

Or you could try to
make a lot of money,

buy things for your
house, grow, acquire.

buy things for your
house, grow, acquire.

And really, the way I visualized
it was almost like a bowling

alley here, in that if I went
down one path or the other,

it was like getting
stuck in a gutter.

To achieve maximum
success, you had

to balance the two
achievements together

to get the highest
level of achievement,
which is right down the middle.

If you went too far to
one side or the other,

you'd actually get stuck on
a local maxim on either side.

So this is basically the
way I was visualizing

a certain region of
the possibility space

within the Sims the
players would encounter.

We use that as a guideline
for tuning the game.

We use that as a guideline
for tuning the game.

After we actually were really
in deep tuning of the game--

we had thousands of
players playing it--

we, in fact, were actually
mapping the real possibility

of space they were
going through,

and we were actually looking at
how the players would fan out
across these dimensions.

These are graphs here
of the way players
were actually fanning out.

At first, we saw too
many on this side,
not enough on that side.

We changed the parameters
of the game a little bit

and actually evened
out so that these

were equally attractive
to a wide group
players, that whole space.

Going a little bit deeper, and
actually, how do we build this?
How do we think about it?
How do we engineer it?

I needed to find
two things here,
the way I think about them.
What is structure?
What is something made of?
What are its parts?

A structure of a
tree, it has a trunk.
It has branches.
It has leaves.

Then there are dynamics,
and this is process.
This is what happens over time.

In this case, it's what
can happen to a tree?
How does it grow?
Can you cut it down?
Can you cut it down?
Can you turn it into firewood?
What happens over the seasons?

So those are all
the dynamics that

can happen to a
tree, which are very

different than the
structure of a tree.

From that, I started
imagining the different things

I use as a designer to
build these systems.

And structurally, I
basically think in terms
of three types of structure.
One is what I call agents.

These are objects that can move
around, interact in a world
somehow.
Next is networks.

These are things that are
connected through some type

These are things that are
connected through some type
of relationship formally.
And it could be relationships.
It could be economic.
It could be biological.
It could be anything.
And the last one is layers.

And this tends to
be more spatial.

Something like
Sim City, there's,
basically, the pollution layer.
There's the traffic layer.

These are things
that are specialized.

And everything in the
game, like Sim City,
is one of these three things.

It's either an agent,
a network, or layer.

The road, basically, is a
network of intersections
connecting areas.

Something like pollution,
crime are layers.

Something like pollution,
crime are layers.

Cars moving around, people
around, even buildings

are agents, sitting on the
landscape with some identity
and some parameters.

So that's the typologies,
or the structure, of games,
the way I think of systems

Next, when we get into dynamics,
any of these topologies,

any one of these dynamics can
occur, things like propagation.

any one of these dynamics can
occur, things like propagation.

How does something
spread through that?

Growth, grouping, order,
allocation, mapping,

specialization, all
these are dynamics that
occur within these typologies.

In some sense, these
are now the verbs.

The topologies are
the nouns that we're
building the game out of.
These dynamics are the verbs.

And lastly, how do
we think about this?

What is our underlying metaphor
for bringing these things
together?

And that's what
I call paradigms.

And that's what
I call paradigms.

Initially, there
were things way back
in the '40s called cybernetics.

But really, it was very simple
systems, like a thermostat.

And originally,
this was developed

for things like autopilot, a
very simple machine control.

Governors on steam
engines, even,

are an example of a
cybernetic system.

But in essence, it's a
very simple, little system

trying to seek a behavior,
seek some set point.
It might be temperature.

It might be the speed
of an engine, whatever.

It was only in the '50s,
when the very first

primitive computers
started coming around,

that the idea of system
dynamics came out.

that the idea of system
dynamics came out.

A guy named Jay Forrester kind
of came up with this concept.
And it's almost hydrological.

It's almost based upon
a chemical refinery

in that in system dynamics,
you just basically have valves
and flows and containers.

A container might be population
or it might be number of cars.

A flow might be birth
rate or death rate.

And you have little algorithms
that will adjust the flows.

For the birth rate,
death rate, you

can see what the
population does over time.

And he would build these
very elaborate models

And he would build these
very elaborate models

of very complicated systems,
things like the world--
food production.

Or in fact, he was
the first person

to actually build a city model
using this kind of paradigm.

The next one I'm
going to talk about

is cellular automata, which
really kind of came to its own

when PCs were really
starting to come out

and people had access
to cheaper computers.

Although, in fact,
cellular automata were
predated system dynamics.

Cellular automata are
basically the idea
that there's a grid and cells.

And these cells can
either be on or off

And these cells can
either be on or off
or have quantities in them.

But basically, all the
dynamics within that

are based upon the neighbors and
the behavior of the neighbors.

The simplest example of
this is a game called Life.

John Conway, a mathematician,
came up with this very simple
system, and it's a grid.

Actually, I'm going to
go to the whiteboard,

just to explain this because
it's actually quite simple.

So in Conway's Life, you
basically have a little world.
It's a grid.

Within this grid, every cell can
either have one of two states.

Within this grid, every cell can
either have one of two states.

It's either alive, it is full,
or it's dead and it's off.

Now, the rules
for Life basically

say that if one cell, right
here, has exactly three

neighbors-- and we're counting
all the neighbors like that.

If there are exactly three
cells alive around it,

like so, this empty
cell now comes to life.

On the next turn, the
new cell appears here.

Now, if a given cell
is already alive

Now, if a given cell
is already alive

and it has three or two
neighbors, it stays there.

If it has less than two or
more than three, it dies.

So this one only has one
neighbor, so it dies.

So basically, that's the whole
rule set for Conway's Life.
Now, it sounds very simple.

You're just counting whether
it has two or three neighbors

and whether it comes
to life or dies.

Turns out that when
you turn this on

and you put a few
cells in there,

there's an explosion
of complexity.

there's an explosion
of complexity.

All this stuff starts
happening, really unpredictable,
surprising stuff.

And people have studied
this thing for years.
I spent months studying.

In fact, I taught
myself programming

trying to program
Life and make it
faster and faster and faster.

As an example, if you
put this shape into Life

at the very beginning
and just start it,

it will explode into this whole
set of hundreds of things,

and start moving around
and have behavior.

and start moving around
and have behavior.

And it's always exactly
the same every time.
It's deterministic.

But it's all a result of
the two simple little rules.

And this is one of the
best examples of emergence

that Conway, who programmed
this, discovered it.

There was no way he
could have predicted

the elaborate
behaviors that were

going to happen in this little
world based upon those two
rules.

It just emerges as
a result of that.
And it's emergent complexity.

So you have this amazingly
complex, little world

that's emerging out of this
incredibly simple, little rule
set.
set.

Somebody asked me just recently
what my favorite game was,
and it's Go.

And the reason to Go
is my favorite game

is because Go has very
much the same property.

Go has two very simple
rules, one of which
almost never happens.

But yet the strategy of
Go is incredibly complex,
relative to the rules set.

And for me, that's a wonderful
aesthetic for game design.

When it's the simplest set of
rules that you can create that

leads to the widest
range of complexity

and the most interesting
world that you can explore,
with strategy and behavior.

Cellular automata actually
became a key part of Sim City

Cellular automata actually

to a system dynamics
model, like Jay Forrester had.

with whatever.
Let's say population.

And then little valves
that would control.

This might be death rate.

that we add for migration,

Now, Jay Forrester came up with

and people started trying to
model a lot of different things
with it.

Back in the late
'60s, early '70s,

there was a group that
started building what they
called the World Dynamic model.

And they actually started
modeling the world economy,

food production, population
growth, all this stuff,

to get some sense of where
the world was headed.

In fact, they started a group
called the Club of Rome,

and there was a very
famous book published

and there was a very
famous book published
called "The Limits to Growth."

And in that book,
they were basically

showing the results of
their world simulation

that they were
running around 1970.

And it was showing that
the world economy would
collapse around 1985 to 1990.

And food production,
people would starve.
And it didn't happen.

What turned out is they
looked back at the model

and they found that they were
off on a few little factors.

They didn't foresee the Green
Revolution, for instance,

that the efficiency of food
production per land area

was going to go up a little
bit more than they thought.

was going to go up a little
bit more than they thought.

And what was surprising
was that that little

bit that they were off led to
an incredibly different result
than what really happened.

And that was really
our first inkling

into what became known
as chaos theory, the idea

that sometimes the initial
starting position of something

can lead to a totally
different outcome

if it's just a
little bit displaced.

A good way to think
about chaos theory,

we have basically, what
we call, chaotic systems
and stable systems.

If I take a bowl, for
instance, like that,

If I take a bowl, for
instance, like that,

and I drop a marble into
it, it might land here
or I might drop it there.

Either way, it's going
to go around a little bit

and it's going to pretty
much end up at the bottom.
OK, that's a stable system.

A chaotic system, if we take
that bowl and we invert it,

like so, and we drop a ball
and displace it a little bit,

now if it lands here, it
might roll way off over here.

If it lands right there, it
might roll way off over there.

So this is really
a chaotic system,

where a very small change
in the initial position

can lead to a wildly
different outcome.

can lead to a wildly
different outcome.

And that's what they discovered
in the World Dynamic model.

And all of a
sudden, chaos theory

started putting real
limits on things

that we could predict
with simulations.

Turns out that
things like weather,

and even other things

tend to be chaotic so
that even if we have

a very deep level
of unpredictability
to these kind of a system.

Another direction that
these paradigms have taken
is called network theory.
is called network theory.

And a network is just anything
containing nodes and links,
like that.

Turns out you can visualize

You can visualize biological

Now, it turns out that

Things are just not obvious.

just randomly, it turns

a fully connected
network, basically,
for any sized network.

a fully connected network.

more than six steps.
